ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the Portuguese colonial world, formations of identity and empire, and how they resonate in the present-day as articulated in literature.
I became a more conscientious reader and worked heavily on grammar.

I learned how to think critically about different books and identify underlying themes that connect the books together. This class was very helpful in developing my skills as a writer, particularly with analyzing works of fiction. I also learned about the Portuguese diaspora and the breadth of their influence in the world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Professor Jackson's breadth of knowledge is amazing and the reading list for this class is so special. You won't encounter most of these texts elsewhere in the academy, and I especially enjoyed the novels by Pinto, Couto, Agualusa and Saramago. The unit on Braslia was also a highlight  the prose by Lispector and Niemeyer's statement on the pilot plan are beautiful, powerful, political literary works. 

The class was more of a lecture than a seminar, and the lectures weren't always particularly well-organized. I think there could have been a lot more discussion (especially because the students generally seemed very excited & engaged  there's a lot of reading, but my impression is that everyone or nearly everyone was doing it & was ready to talk about it). There weren't clear directions for presenting on a given week's readings, and we sort of abandoned the practice a couple weeks into the semester. If more thought was given to the structure of a given class period & to the supplementary materials that would be presented in each meeting, and if student engagement, dialogue & active learning were higher priorities, this could be a really wonderful class.

Strengths: Professor Jackson is extremely passionate about this class and that makes for a great learning experience. The class is very well structured and you learn about a new city each class. Professor Jackson gives great feedback and is very understanding. 

Weaknesses: Class discussion can sometimes feel slow and sometimes is more of a lecture than a discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes  the Lusophone world is so fascinating and woefully understudied in disciplines like literature, history, urbanism, ER&M and sociology. It expanded my conceptions of colonialism, hybridity and diaspora and introduced me to some amazing writers.
Yes, this is a fantastic class! I would highly recommend this class to anyone that is trying to develop their writing skills in a topic that is very interesting and most likely new to them.

extras.title: LAST 394 01/LITR 294 01/PORT 394 01/PORT 960 01 - World Cities and Narratives TR
